awd_titl_txt: ABI Development: systemPipeR - automated NGS workflow and report generation environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Next-generation sequencing (NGS) has revolutionized how research is carried out in many areas of biology by allowing researchers to sequence genomes and transcriptomes on a routine basis. However, the analysis of NGS data remains a major obstacle to the efficient utilization of the technology. While substantial effort has been invested on the development of software dedicated to the individual analysis steps of NGS experiments, insufficient resources are currently available for integrating the individual software components into automated workflows capable of running the analysis of most types of NGS applications from start-to-finish in a time-efficient and reproducible manner. This Development project will address this need by enhancing systemPipeR, a popular R/Bioconductor software package. The project will have significant impact on a wide range of scientific communities and our society at large by allowing to translate NGS data into biologically relevant knowledge in a time-efficient and reproducible manner. This will accelerate many research and discovery projects in academia and industry, where NGS technologies play an important role. Extensive educational resources for interdisciplinary training at the intersect of genome and computational biology will be provided. Training will be offered to scientists, postdoctoral researchers, graduate and undergraduate students. Members of underrepresented groups will participate in all aspects of this project while supporting diversity. Extensive online tutorials will be provided to maximize the educational outreach of the activities. 

The specific aims of this project are: (AIM 1) Enhancements to systemPipeR?s user interface and the workflow design framework will greatly simplify the process of running workflows, generating automated reports and designing new workflows. It will also improve user-friendliness to make systemPipeR equally useful for R and non-R users, as well as biologists without any expert knowledge in bioinformatics. The execution plan of this aim includes the design of a central workflow control user interface and the adaptation of new community standards to further increase the reproducibility of analysis workflows. (AIM 2) Automated analysis workflows will be developed for a wide range of additional NGS applications. Most of these workflows will be designed in collaboration with experts of the corresponding NGS application areas. Suggestions from the community will be incorporated as well. Sample templates will be provided for the supported NGS applications to create workflow instances with a single command fully populated with all input data and environment settings. (AIM 3) The project will also have a strong focus on community integration and performance evaluations provided by its current and future users. This includes options for users to contribute code or entire workflows, and extensive training of the target audience to analyze NGS data with systemPipeR and related resources. The URL of the systemPipeR project website is: http://girke.bioinformatics.ucr.edu/systemPipeR.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT: This project has developed systemPipe, a flexible software environment for processing complex scientific data using automated analysis workflows and creating reproducible scientific reports. The software enhancements developed during the funding period of this grant have transformed systemPipe into a multi-purpose community software that is flexible enough to handle a wide range of small- to large-scale data. These functionalities are important to standardize data analysis routines, maximize their reproducibility, and reduce the time to process and translate large-scale data into discoveries. This is particularly important for the analysis of high-throughput data, often referred to as big data, including next-generation sequencing (NGS) data used in many life science disciplines. This trend has led to an explosion of data of increasing size and complexity making it now more and more challenging for experimental researchers to extract knowledge from their data. As a result, they have to spend a substantial amount of time on data analysis tasks. To address the needs of both experimental and computational researchers, systemPipe is composed of three major modules: (1) systemPipeR provides core functionalities for defining workflows, interacting with command-line software, and executing both R and/or command-line software, as well as generating publication-quality analysis reports. (2) systemPipeShiny integrates a graphical user interface for managing workflows and visualizing results interactively in an intuitive manner. (3) systemPipeWorkflow offers a collection of pre-configured workflow templates. For efficient management of complex analysis routines, a generic workflow management framework has been developed. This central design concept facilitates the management and execution of complex data analysis workflows. Another important advancement is the adoption of the Common Workflow Language (CWL) for systemPipe's command-line interface. CWL is a widely used community standard. Its usage enhances the flexibility and reusability of systemPipe, such as support of other data analysis environments and programming languages. Additional improvements for running large-scale analyses in systemPipe include: substantially reduced learning times for users to master a wide range of analysis tasks without limiting themselves to a set of predefined tools; accelerated analysis and compute times due to automation and parallelization of end-to-end analysis workflows; auto-generation of dynamic analysis reports offer a high degree of reproducibility; and the integration of the statistical programming environment R provides access to a large ecosystem of powerful data modeling and visualization resources. The systemPipe project website is available here:  https://systempipe.org.

BROADER IMPACTS: The analysis resources developed by this project have reached a large and broad user community. The software is now downloaded by over 12,000 unique IP addresses annually. Current users are from many career levels and backgrounds, including undergraduate and graduate students, data analysts, postdocs, faculty and researchers from industry. Their areas of specialization include various life science disciplines, statistics, computational biology, as well as data science. Moreover, the project has and will continue to encourage scientists to incorporate automated and reproducible data analysis strategies into their daily research. Substantial educational resources for interdisciplinary training at the intersect of computational biology and genome biology have been provided by this project. This includes workshops instructed at Bioconductor conferences and an online genome data science class. Extensive online tutorials for using the systemPipe software have been developed and are hosted on the public website of this project. This online material broadens the educational outreach of the project. Moreover, the project has trained three graduate students, two postdocs and six undergraduate students. Summer internships were provided to undergraduate students from an NSF-sponsored REU program for undergraduates without research experience at UC Riverside. Many of the students in this program are members of underrepresented groups at local community colleges. These internships have exposed the REU students to state-of-the-art data analysis strategies. Overall the integrated software development and outreach program have maximized the broader impacts of the project.
